text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many patients don’t like that term. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um so that’s just hormone resistant. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In that context only, if you give back super-high doses of testosterone to the patient, and the way that we do that is we give an intra-muscular injection. It’s an injection of testosterone into the muscle that is either thigh muscle or the butt muscle. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: Uh, and then look at the other options. So, is that, is the one that is phase one is that, that window like a real tight window. That seven days from now, it’s gonna be closed? Doctor: Umm. I don’t know that. So, when I spoke to Dr. P_, all she let me know was that there was a slot. You know, that would be something that we would say once you’ve decided or that we’ve given you the consent form that we have a potential patient who’s interested, that they would save that slot for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they would, I assume, that there is going to need to be a twenty-eight day washout of your current therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, maybe that you have to repeat scans prior to that. Um, the adrenal glands. The, the big wild card there right now what I can clearly state that it is not specific. I don’t know what it is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, that’s the radiologists can’t agree on what it is. Patient: So, would I have to have something done to go into the adrenal glands or, uh, the, the tests that confirm that whether it is cancer or not cancer? Doctor: Um, no. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. And then if you decided to go with chemotherapy, it would be just one of the many spots that we would watch for change in response to.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? So we’ll check probably after about twelve weeks, huh, about how it’s going. Huh, but our job will be to cheer lead you through the first three to four cycles, huh, adjusting the dose if you’re having side effects and they’re too severe. But most people are able to get through it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so my recommendation is that we stop the abiraterone, continue the prednisone. If you’re interested in the clinical trial, I can at least start with, huh, printing it out for you, and letting you read it, and see how often you need to be here, let the nurse know that you’re potentially interested, and she can, huh, do insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if they say your insurance is not going to pay for it, the decision’s made. Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
